page.title: 07FARMING/OVERTON+MIDDLETON
page.content: Until around 1945,Overton was largely a farming community.The farms were generally small,and farmers shared the grazing on the marshes.Since then,much land has been sold for building,and some farms have amalgamated.Around a dozen farms,using the name "farm",are now private dwellings,with little or no land.Those remaining are mixed farms, some milk and beef,others fatstock,or rearing sheep.There is 1 piggery;hay and silage in summer,but very little arable land;a few potatoes,and barley being the only crops.The land is fertile and free-draining.A number of families,with large gardens or a few acres,keep geese,turkeys and poultry, and many have goats.In most cases,sons will succeed fathers on the land.Land prices are so high,that some farmers have formed a "co-operative".
